H0.text: In classical architecture, what is the plain-faced portion, usually rectangular, of a pedestal between the base and the cornice. Die

H1.text: In classical architecture, what is the plain-faced portion, usually rectangular, of a pedestal between the base and the cornice. Shaft

H2.text: In classical architecture, what is the plain-faced portion, usually rectangular, of a pedestal between the base and the cornice. Plinth

H3.text: In classical architecture, what is the plain-faced portion, usually rectangular, of a pedestal between the base and the cornice. Dado

A4.text: The name was first used in English as an architectural term for the part of a pedestal between the base and the cornice.

A5.text: By extension, the dado becomes the lower part of a wall when the pedestal is treated as being continuous along the wall, with the cornice becoming the dado rail.
